channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jakarta Journal: Suharto’s Indonesian Legacy, 15 Years Later
item.description: Suharto, the army leader turned president, resigned 15 years ago on Monday, and his legacy stirs conflicting emotions among Indonesians.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: A street vendor at the entrance to the street where former President Suharto lived in an elaborate complex.

item.title: Prime Minister Li Keqiang of China Arrives in India for Talks
item.description: Indian officials welcomed Prime Minister Li Keqiang for talks focused on economic ties, though a recent border dispute still resonates.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Li Keqiang, center, arriving in New Delhi on Sunday. At left is E. Ahamed, India’s minister for external affairs.

item.title: North Korea Seized Chinese Fishing Boat
item.description: The seizure of the boat and its crew, which took place more than two weeks ago but was just made public, signaled growing tensions between longtime allies.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Many of Spain’s Sephardic Jews Still Waiting for Citizenship
item.description: New rules announced six months ago to ease the naturalization process have yet to be put into practice.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: David Cameron Facing Criticism From Own Party
item.description: As a fellow Conservative accused Prime Minister David Cameron of “running scared” from the party’s right wing, that right wing continued to show its displeasure.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Fresh Israeli Face Plays Down Political Decline
item.description: Yair Lapid presented an austerity budget this month with tax increases and subsidy cuts that hit hard the people he claimed to represent.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: As finance minister, Yair Lapid has presented an unpopular budget, undercutting the successes that made his party the second largest in Parliament.

item.title: Chinese Hackers Resume Attacks on U.S. Targets
item.description: A cyberunit of China’s People’s Liberation Army was back in business after going silent for the past few months.
item.category: RSA, The Security Division of EMC Corporation
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: The headquarters of Unit 61398, center, in Shanghai. The unit of the People’s Liberation Army is believed to have resumed its attacks on American companies and government agencies.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Day the Music Died in Mali
item.description: Can Mali, or any country, survive if militants ban all music?
item.dc:creator: By SUJATHA FERNANDES

item.title: Russia Expels Former U.S. Embassy Official
item.description: Thomas Firestone, a former Justice Department official who had been working in Moscow as a lawyer, was declared “persona non grata” this month, possibly because he reportedly had rebuffed an effort to recruit him as a spy.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Lens Blog: Israeli Report Casting New Doubts on Shooting in Gaza
item.description: A new report by the Israeli government called into question a well-known image of a Palestinian boy and his father, caught in the crossfire of a gun battle in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Bomb Suspect’s Trip Sheds Light on Caucasus War
item.description: A visit to Dagestan last year by Tamerlan Tsarnaev, a suspect in the Boston bombings, has drawn attention to the guerrilla conflict in the North Caucasus, in which most young men who get involved do not return alive.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: People praying recently in a mosque in Khasavyurt, Russia, in Dagestan. The region is the arena for low-boil guerrilla warfare.

item.title: Georgian Officials React Slowly to Anti-Gay Attack
item.description: An inquiry into the attack that included rock-throwing priests caught on television cameras has led to no arrests.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and OLESYA VARTANYAN

item.title: H&M Led Labor Breakthrough by European Retailers
item.description: The Swedish retail giant H&M faced public pressure to accelerate its efforts to improve garment-factory conditions, though it had no ties to a disaster in Bangladesh.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Magnus Laupa for The New York Times

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: Coen Brothers’ ‘Inside Llewyn Davis’ Is Popular at Cannes
item.description: The Coen brothers’ “Inside Llewyn Davis,” which follows a New York folk musician, injected some levity into the Cannes Film Festival.
item.dc:creator: By MANOHLA DARGIS
item.media:description: Oscar Isaac plays the title character in “Inside Llewyn Davis” by Ethan and Joel Coen.

item.title: Syrian Army Moves to Rebel-Held Qusayr
item.description: Pro-government fighters are reported to hold more than half of the border city of Qusayr, in a critical setback for rebel forces.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: The battle for Qusayr, Syria, raged on Sunday. A photo from a citizen journalist captured what was said to be the results of military airstrikes and artillery assaults.

item.title: Killing of Pakistani Politician Shakes New Voting Round
item.description: A day after the killing of a prominent opposition party figure, turnout in a wealthy district of Karachi, Pakistan’s largest city, was minimal.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Syrian Troops Said to Strike Town Near Lebanon
item.description: The Syrian military on Sunday launched an offensive to retake a strategic rebel-held town near the Lebanese border, a government official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Condé Nast Offers Fashion Industry Courses
item.description: The 10-week and yearlong courses introduce students to the history of fashion, designers, fashion journalism, retail, business, marketing and public relations.
item.dc:creator: By D. D. GUTTENPLAN

item.title: Letter From Washington: Distortions That Still Require Decisive Action
item.description: On none of the current so-called scandals in Washington is there any suggestion of wrongdoing by President Barack Obama. But there are bold actions Mr. Obama could consider.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

item.title: Launchings by North Korea Raise Tensions
item.description: North Korea launched a short-range projectile into waters off its east coast as South Korea condemned the act and urged the North to accept a proposal for talks.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Joseph Farman, 82, Is Dead; Discovered Ozone Hole
item.description: Mr. Farman’s single-minded and at times officially derided study of atmospheric changes in the Antarctic led to one of the most important environmental discoveries of the 20th century.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO

item.title: Kenneth N. Waltz, Who Helped Shape International Relations as a Discipline, Dies at 88
item.description: Mr. Waltz, who was a senior research scholar at Columbia, was a pre-eminent thinker who was known for his contrarian, debate-provoking ideas.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: In a Journey on a Crumbling Railway, a Picture of a Nation’s Troubles
item.description: A journey across Pakistan’s crumbling railway presents a picture of the country’s troubles: natural disasters and hardened insurgencies, abject poverty and feudal kleptocrats, and an economy near meltdown.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trying to fix the tracks near Lahore. Pakistan’s railways, which once linked a fractious young nation, have been neglected.

item.title: Exposés of China’s Elite a Big Lure in Hong Kong
item.description: Visitors from mainland China turn to Hong Kong bookstores for forbidden delights: shelves of scandal-packed exposés about their Communist Party masters.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The People’s Recreation Community bookstore in Hong Kong, which carries scandalous books about Communist leaders.

item.title: Maze Prison’s Future Stirs Up Ghosts of Its Past
item.description: With a peace center planned for Maze prison, home of an I.R.A. hunger strike, some in Northern Ireland are revisiting the complex story of the Troubles.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY
item.media:description: Maze prison in 1979 in Northern Ireland. A center for the study of peace and conflict resolution is planned for the site.
